metadata.title: What is F1?
metadata.description: Highest class of single-seater auto racing sanctioned by the Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile (FIA)
metadata.author: Branden Sambersond
metadata.note: This is an article that should be published on Monday

image.caption: Racing Driver On A Pit Stop

text.p: Formula One, also known as F1, is the highest class of single-seater auto racing sanctioned by the Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile (FIA). It is considered to be one of the most prestigious and competitive forms of motorsport in the world.

Formula One cars are the fastest road course racing cars in the world, with the ability to reach speeds of over 200 miles per hour (320 km/h) on a modern race track. The cars are designed and built by a handful of top-tier teams, including Ferrari, Mercedes-AMG, Red Bull Racing, and Williams, among others. Each team has a limited number of engines and tires available for the season, which adds an element of strategy to pit stops and race planning.

Races are typically held on purpose-built circuits or on public roads closed for racing. The cars must be capable of reaching incredible speeds within a very short distance, and the drivers must be skilled and experienced to handle these high speeds and the intense G-forces involved in cornering and braking.

The Formula One season consists of a series of races held around the world, known as Grands Prix. The top drivers and teams are ranked based on their performance throughout the season, with the driver and team earning the most points being declared the champion. The season culminates in November with the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix, which also serves as the final race of the season.

text.p: Formula One has a large global following and is widely considered to be one of the most technologically advanced forms of motorsport. The sport is known for its glamorous and wealthy owners, as well as its high-profile drivers, many of whom have become celebrities in their own right. The sport also has a long history of innovation, with new technologies and materials constantly being introduced to improve performance.

In addition to the on-track competition, Formula One is also known for its political intrigue and backroom deals, with teams and drivers often jockeying for position and influence within the sport. The sport has a complex and convoluted governing structure, with multiple layers of management and decision-making, which can sometimes lead to controversy and conflict.

Overall, Formula One is a highly competitive and technologically advanced form of motorsport that attracts a large global following and is widely considered to be one of the most prestigious forms of racing in the world.
